Name: Lightning Fall: A Novel of Disaster

ReviewList.Text: The thinly veiled portrait of Hillary Clinton as a maniacal president lessens this otherwise excellent and wide-ranging story of America's collapse after an EMP. No zombies, no aliens, no plague, no asteroids here. Just America brought to its knees and how people from the president to ordinary people to street thugs respond. I look forward to reading the sequel in 2015,  however this book presents a complete story that stands on its own.

Extremely well researched and written. A cast of diverse characters that are believable and could be met on the streets of America today. The plot has the makings of our worst nightmares. As reading entertainment it is well worth the purchase price. As a primer for what may be ahead of us it is undervalued.

I share the assessments of reviewers, other than the obvious leftists, who gave the book one or two stars.  Their comments are pretty much on target.  To those, I'll add this:  The book (the Kindle edition, anyway) was very poorly edited.  The typos, punctuation errors, grammatical mistakes and crazy errors in the story are too distracting.  One example:  Two of the key locations in the story are San Francisco and Muncie, IN.  At one point, a woman in Muncie dials 911 and the operator answers "San Francisco 911."  Oops.  Overall, the book has the feel of perhaps a second draft that was turned out quickly and self-published after little or no proof reading.
Enjoyed the book! As the various subplots started to connect, overall story was enhanced.  Really liked how the impact of political decisions was brought to life in "small town" America.

Frightenly realistic. Tense fast paced action in the aftermath of an EMP and nuclear attack on the US. A portrayal of how quickly our fragile modern way of life can crumble. Once you start reading you can't put it down.

Lightning Fall really exploits the fragility of our modern dependence on the systems that our lives depend on. The book was fast paced, plenty of action, and plenty of food for thought. Highly recommend.
What a great PAW story.  A completely plausible set of circumstances, combined with realistic dialog and characters.  Not your typical survivalist story - much, much better.
Book is well written, and a gripping story.  I will have to look up other works by Quick. And by some more food for the pantry.

In the tradition of Eric L. Harry's Arc Light, with a little bit of his Invasion thrown in, Lightning Fall offers a frightening look at the aftereffects of an EMP attack on the western United States, that threatens to not only condemn untold millions to death in the affected areas, but rend the United States itself asunder, aided by the manipulations of a President (a thinly-veiled Hillary Clinton, complete with First Husband and former President "B.J.") bound and determined to "never let a crisis go to waste" and use it to ensure enduring political power for her party.  The author's extensive research into not only EMP effects themselves but disaster preparedness is readily apparent throughout the book, and his depiction of the machinations of Washington politics, as well as the efforts of other nations to take advantage of America's weakness, are also on the mark.  The "To be continued..." note at the end left me frustrated, but I consider that to be the mark of a good story that I want to see the culmination of; I'll certainly be eager to see the sequel.

Reminiscent of "One Second After" Lightning Fall treats an attack on the United States from a more broadbased perspective.  An EMP attack over San Francisco leaves the US west of the Rockies without power, without mobility, and starving millions.  At the same time a nuke explodes on the New Orleans waterfront leaving that port destroyed and unusable for years.  The third attempt happens a minute too late and is shot down before it can cripple the east coast.  Bill Quick looks at what this would do to the US across the country; from San Francisco's gay preppers, to Muncie Indiana's mid-western small town folks, to suburban Philadelphia life changes.  And for those caught in the brunt of the attack life becomes hard, brutal, and short.  Washington DC is spared and the only hope for the country is a thinly disguised Bill and Hillary Clinton.  The only downside to the book - it's half over with the sequel coming in Spring 2015.  If you're paying attention to world affairs, this book will alarm and frighten you.
All the characters were very realistic. What does the author know that we should know? I recommend this book! It should be a warning for all.

I really enjoyed the diversity of characters presented by the author in this book and I look forward to reading the next installment.  In the main, the story was well written and informative.  My only complaint was the time spent on the political wrangling, but I can see that side of the story needed telling as well.  I would have preferred to see more about how the folks on the Gulf Coast were making out, but hopefully that will come in Book 2.  For fans of disaster stories and survival, I recommend this one to you.

With the hacking of the powergrid last week, The automatic weapon fire on a Silicone valley transformer last summer, and the North Korean missle launchers on a freighter discovered in the Panama canal our power grid is under attack. If power were lost nearly 100 million Americans could die. Scary stuff and Bill Quick describes the post-apocalyptic world perfectly. I did enjoy the book but not the prospects of such an event.

A fairly engaging scifi read ... although many Democrats & Liberals may not appreciate the treatment (through loosely-veiled main characters) of Bill and especially - Hillary Clinton. Some of the book's elements are not as realistically-believable as many readers might prefer (myself included), but the main plot and action does move along at a fast  and interesting pace.

This book will quite probably scare you.  Far too much of it is possible and that is what makes it work.  It has it all  Rouge terrorists, corrupt self serving politicians.  If you like collapse,  political,  world gone mad give this a try  the only criticism I can level is there are a lot of characters and at times it was hard to keep who  was whom
Very realistic, especially the depiction of the "Carter" Whitehouse.  Amazon, it's very annoying for you to tell me how many words I have to write, or that I have to write anything at all.

The premise is very accurate and concerning. The book is also heavily skewed against what is obviously the Clintons and the Democratic Party in general. If that bothers you, you may not enjoy the book.
I found this to be one of the better stories of it's kind.  I look forward to the second book.

This eerily echoes my main fear for the collapse of the country.  It won't be an invasion.  It will be the combination of a narcissistic Washington class long practicing self aggrandizement and a single cataclysmic event that knocks over delicately balanced dominoes.  The dependent class, so carefully nurtured over the five decades are utterly unable to take care of themselves.  This isn't a novel. It's a prophecy.

I read a positive review of this great book on hotair.com and am not sorry to have picked it up.  The premise for the story line is believable with compelling "good guys" and despicable "bad guys" especially the partisan "democrats win at all cost" president.  While this isn't about politics, it certainly helps tie it together.

Great story, easy read.  Made me think about if civilization did collapse for a period of time--what have I done to prepare.  As my son says sarcastically; "Based on a true story."  But, this time it is in the future.  It could happen.

I will certainly buy other books by this author. Great writing style, engaging. Did not weave in any factual data about how many would die from lack of medicines, like diabetes meds, but did develop powerful, believable political scenarios.

One of very very few books I can think of which approaches Stephen King's "The Stand" in scale.  Just really brilliant, plausible, and horrifying.  Pretty much furious that I will have to wait some indeterminate time to see the next installment.  Mr. Quick--I hope you're writing twenty hours a day, dude.  Just awesome.

Outstanding!  Sadly, Mr. Quick is on target with the realities that many of us fear.  The book definitely had my heart racing at times and had me thinking of what I would do and whether or not I'm as prepared as I think I am.  I'm greatly anticipating the next installment.
Very plausible story line.  Strong familiar characters.  Can't wait to see book 2.  Feels current in timing, almost expect to see these events on the evening news.
It informs and entertains, and I look forward to the next book in the series.  It seems to me to be a very plausible path that the future might take.
Engrossing, on the edge, politically believable .can't wait for the next installment hope it's just as good as this one
Great story and scary cause it could really happen. Took one star off for numerous spelling and grammar errors.
Nicely written, good plot, fast pace -- very enjoyable, especially for the price.

Bill Quick has put together a surreally accurate story of how tragedy would unfold, with the thinly veiled Villains true to their real life counterparts, their main opponent a Jack Ryan type that is sorely needed.  The multi faceted tale covers a wide variety of locations and personalities, creating both hope and despair, joy and sadness so suddenly you will find yourself stunned on more than one occasion.

Good read, hard to put down.  Thought provoking but realistic premise, a doomsday scenario that could/would happen if certain things came into play.  Presents a plausible political, economic and human impact scenario.  The fact that the author weaves a Bill/Hilliary presidency into the mix is amusing, could even foretell our political future.  I look forward to the sequel.
Reasonably well written.  Not pedantic nor preachy.  Character development weak yet I am still looking forward to the next in the series.

I liked that it took in the whole country not just one town (One Minute After) and the portrayal of the Carters was  priceless and instructive. BTW, love the pop  up words. Many typos-no proof  reading?
Horrifying and fantastic in equal measure. An electromagnetic pulse attack is the setting for a political drama as well lots of action. Could have used some zombies, though.
Getting this book for $3.99 on Kindle is one of the great bargains ever.  I couldn't put it down.  I'm going to buy the sequel the day it comes out next year, regardless of the price.
I was fascinated by the idea of an EMP event being used to destroy the west coast. The results seem all too likely.
Fast paced story that really makes you think about how Delicate civil society is. I look forward to the next installment.
I can't wait for the next one!  Very detailed and very plausible description of what could happen to this great country in the near future.

The book is a fascinating look at what an electro-magnetic pulse would do, including the horror that results when NOTHING electrical works. The book is a bit tendentious with its references to the standard bogey-men (Mideastern terrorists) who are in bed with Mexico and China to bring the U.S. to its knees. The President is a thinly-veiled caricature of Hillary Clinton, and her antics in the book provide red, raw meat for right-wing nuts like me, but really are irrelevant to the overall arc of the story. Entertaining and moderately informative - I recommend it.
This was a genuine page turner and I am one of those who usually reads the beginning of the book and skips to the end to see how it turns out - I read every word of this one.

Good story. Enjoyed the action, but this book really needs a good editor. Missing words, added letters to sentences, and too numerous mistakes were extremely annoying. I sure hope Mr. Quick' s next book is well edited. What a shame. Don' t know if I'll buy the next book.
Good book. Well plotted. Really enjoyable. I suggest the Author use a story editor on the next one to help him out a bit.
Well framed and chilling look at a very real threat all-to ignored by the 'leaders' or our country.  All of which is presented in a compelling storyline.
This book was a once started unable to put down. Awesome character building with plot twist and turns. Can not wait for book 2 come on spring 2015.
Well written and suspenseful - thought provoking as well. Puts a reasonable and understandable case about what could happen to America

If you are a fan of disaster books like "Alas, Babylon" or "Lucifer's Hammer" you will enjoy this book immensely.  The plot is what happens when Arab terrorists try to blow up nuclear emps to shut down the USA.  Only one works, and the rest of the story is how people across the country deal with the problems from the attack.  It will keep you turning the page, but be warned, it is only the first book in the set.  Next year the second will be out.  But you will be waiting for it.

I'm a fan of cataclysmic/apocalyptic novels if they're well done, as is this one. I'm aware of the author's prior books and blog entries, as well as his political persuasions which I, for the most part, share. This novel has believable characters, both the "normal folks" as well as the thinly-disguised Bill and Hillary figures, and shows the vulnerabilities of the thin veneer of civilization which we so easily take for granted. It contains some good prepper points as well.
So real it will make you think about what could happen to you if the power goes out forever. It will make a great beach read this summer.

Great book from Bill Quick!  I could hardly put it down and only the necessity of needing sleep interfered.  Can't wait for the next book.  Great characters and many cautionary tales for all of us, in many aspects of our lives.
This was an excellent read! I especially enjoyed Bill's take on the liberal politicians reaction to the crisis. Good job Bill!  Can't wait for the next volume.

I'm not a zombie type book fan. I want  scenerios of what could REALLY happen to our country if the SHTF and this book delivers.  I live in VA Beach and worry that an attack would be here. Instead, this attack was primarily on the west coast . So thanks for keeping ME alive ! :) The only disappointment is knowing I have to wait a year for a follow up!

This is one of the worst books I have attempted to read recently.  A member of my book group recommended it, but I could not make myself finish it, especially when I discovered it would be continued in another book.  The premise is interesting, but the many scenarios are ridiculous. I understand a movie is being made, but I won't be seeing it.

America and her citizens face a cruel and ingenious attack. Thru well-plotted twists and turns, across the clearly rendered landscape, towns, and cities of the West and Midwest, housewives, scientists, soldiers, bureaucrats, parents, and children, all do their best to save something from the wreckage, and begin to strike back at the evil.

I enjoyed this book. The pace was a little slow in the beginning, but as the story and characters developed, it seemed about right. The details regarding the effects of this disaster were accurate as far as I am aware (there were no glaring errors) and it was a good read. I am looking forward to the next installment.

Seriously needs a proofreader!  Besides the grammatical errors throughout the book (and there are a bunch) the premise of the story is intriguing, just not very well done.  Too many stereotypes and a bit on the corny side.

Not very subtle (especially the characterization of the president and her husband), but if the book helps stimulate discussion about the potential dangers of an EMP attack, Bill Quick will have done us all a great service.

Book was great at getting to the heart of an EMP attack an its problems.  I don't care much for complicated relationships or people (that's just not me) but otherwise a very strong punch of a disaster novel.
Good story and maybe a touch prophetic, given that so many of the parts are moving into place. Let's  hope the author is proven wrong  on all accounts.
Looking forward to the next installment. Characters are relatable and the picture painted and likely societal implications all the more poignant.
I enjoyed this very much and would have given five stars, but I found the many misprints, and spelling errors distracting.
This is an engaging and all too plausible disaster story.  You may also pick up some practical survival tips.
As far as prepper apocalypses go Bill Quick has written a good one. I look forward to the next chapter.
An enjoyable way to kill several hours.  If you like apocalypse fiction this book is worth the read.
the best i have read on the subject in a long time.. Looking forward to the sequel
Very readable and a story that makes you think that it might actually happen.
I wish everyone would read it!  An entertaining and informative book.
A real thriller, captivating, one of the best books I've read very long time, and I read a lot of books.
Good book to get one thinking about EMP from High altitude nuclear blast or from solar flare. I enjoyed book and could not put it down. Await the follow up book.

One of the best post-apocalyptic novels I've read in a long time.  The scenario Bill Quick comes up with is more realistic than most, and the characters are interesting.  I'm looking forward to more books in this series.
Can't wait for the sequel.  The first one was captivating.  There are a lot of viable plot lines left and I am looking forward to the next part.

I've read a lot of EMP books this is just ok if I could've I would have given it 21/2 stars but it wasn't an option. The book definitely was a slow starter, didn't care for some of the story lines. It could've been much shorter with the same out come. I would recommend Lights Out or One Second After if this is your first venture into this genre.
Well written.  I good amount of research must have been done, as this is one of the most technically accurate books I read and I have read most of this type.
Fun read and well researched.
Cannot wait for the sequel!
Too scary -

A bit disappointing.  Way too much time spent on thinly bashing Hillary Clinton and the plot by the Speaker of the House to impeach her.  Get on with the disaster and recovery man!  You started off with a bang and then got off target with liberal bashing.

It was a great read but too much politics and not enough information about waht was happening in the rest of the world..  The plot was OK but the idea that the U.S. would be attacked by nuclear weapons and that the government would do nothing at all about it is ridiculous.  Also  no mention of anything happening in the rest of the world was made. It ended with no resolution and having to wait another year for the n ext installment is just a promotional trick.

This is a very good apocolytic novel that is partly spolied by the author's obvious right wing bias. The references to the clintons under the carter name are kind of funny but it detracts from the seriousness. Also the idea that only democrats put politics first is just too one sided and makes you sceptiical of the book overall. I still recomend it. It could have been a  4 or 5 star.

I was disappointed in the editing and won't be buying the sequel as I felt cheated by the ending. Quick can write well and I'll try another of his books at some point. Can't say I'd recommend this one though.

Dull.  Lotta farfetched speculation that doesn't make any sense at all.  Bad science, too.  Looks like it was written to make money off the tin-foil-hat prepper community.  I got suckered in.  Don't you.

I tried to get through this but just can't get past the 1/4 mark.  This story has been told better recently. First, One Second After tells the story of an EMP attack on the United States much better and The Last Centurion tells the story of liberal ideas, policies and politics during a national - indeed worldwide - disaster much better as well.  That and so-so writing make it not worth one's time. Do yourself a favor and read those other two books instead.  You won't regret it.

It starts with decent suspense and interesting descriptions and quirks for main characters, but then the plot is slowing down and becomes easy predictable. I did read it to the end mostly to find out that it doesn't deviate too much from my projections since the first third of the book.

Story of survival after a near-future terrorist attack that succeeds in nuking New Orleans and EMP-ing the US west of the Rockies. This was very absorbing, although it was obviously more action than character driven. It features a lot of (3rd person tight) viewpoint characters, some only once, but pulls this off without diverting the plot. Could have had 4 stars but lost a star for ridiculous politics (ACORN oh please), praising John Ringo--and boy do this author and Ringo hate, hate, hate the Clintons...but this author is far less supercilious and condescending in tone than Ringo so I kept with it until the end. There is going to be a sequel and I need to read that.

I commend the author for the writing abilities to put together a book such as this. However, in the same breath, I am so glad it's over! WAY TOO MUCH of government. we all are very much aware that when the day comes that we are knocked back to the stone age it will be because of our corrupted government. I read these books to see how the everyday man and woman will try to survive it. This book just rubs salt to the wound. Their are also So Many different groups of people and names and just not my cup of tea! I won't read book two but if you like this style of a book I'm sure you'll like the next one. This book was mainly about the politicians, not the people.

It's an interesting story but I'm not particularly a fan of the writing style of the author. It seems like he has a list of product names that he wants to throw into the story and does so liberally. I don't see it adding to the story that a character drinks a particular brand of Scotch. I really don't need to be reminded of the brand every time the character has a drink.
What if we lost California and New Orleans the same day? How quickly would our 3 days of supplies trickle down into anarchy...and tyranny? Can government help or only seize an opportunity?

Unreadable. I like Bill Quick and was looking forward to this, and I've enjoyed broadly similar tales like Patriots: Surviving the Coming Collapse, by James Wesley Rawles. But, sorry, the quality of the writing was atrocious, and I tired quickly of yet another way to reflect on how one of the early protagonist's struggles as a gay individual related to something or other. Perhaps I should have given this more of a chance, but after thirty or forty pages of making Rawles sound like Saul Bellow in comparison, I gave up. It's an important subject so I'll have to try something else.

There are so many things I didn't like about this read. first there are way too many characters. And because there are so many, very little character development. Too much of what happens in this story is about politics. I guess that's fine if that is what you want to read about. I don't. What really bothered me about this book is that once the lights went out, all minorities contributed nothing more to the story than being there simply to be cultural stereotypes. I really like stories of disaster and survival but I didn't enjoy one thing about this one. Pass.
interesting but politically naive

I really wanted to like this book. I found the author's political views to mirror my own. What I do object to, however, is using the platform of a novel such as this to proselytize for the homosexual agenda. Really, author? Is it necessary for your storyline to describe disgusting homosexual sex acts in graphic detail? I found myself simply skimming over the portions of the book that dealt with the homosexual couple and reading only those sections that did not contain information about their sex lives. For that reason, I cannot bring myself to purchase another of this author's books, nor can I recommend this book to friends.

How about a novel that isn't based on a prepper?  This book skipped all of the terrors of an EMP to focus on politics.  It is more a book on politics than an EMP.  Pages about politicians drinking together but nothing about actual survival following an EMP.  Lame.

Interesting story, but the in-your-face political agenda is too much. One small example (putting aside the blatant Hillary and Bill Clinton caricatures): you do know it's Republicans who refer to the "Democrat party." Democrats themselves would use the term "Democratic Party." Putting the wrong term into the mouths of Democrats gives a jarringly false tone to the dialog.
I got as far as the 2nd sentence of the 2nd paragraph of chapter 2. Glad I was able to get that far in the "look inside" option before I bought the book.

I thought the book was well written and had an entertaining postapocalyptic premise.  That said, the politics ruined the book.  The author just ruined a good book by adding the Faux News talking points.

What if you tried to read a book, but were nearly killed by the avalanche of cliches falling on your head? "Lightning Fall" brings this terrifying vision to life. How many times can the Muslim terrorists come up with a synonym for dog? Is it possible for anyone to say "Great Satan" a million times in 90 seconds? Can the robot-like characters pass as human? If wooden dialog falls in the forest and no one's there to hear it, does it make a horrible creaking sound or is that just the readers crying out in horror? The author has cleverly taken a prosaic disaster story and made it into a parable of the horror that results when the ability to write dialog or believable characters has died.

This is a right-wing prepper's fantasy book. President Millicent Carter (I guess the author expects Hillary to follow Obama to the White House) and her husband, ex-President B.J. (the author is nothing if not obvious) become foul-mouthed tyrants when an EMP destroys the electrical grid west of the Rockies. Any book that represents Tea Party folks as the voice of reason is immediately laughable. And the right wing's insistence on using the term "Democrat Party" paints them as childish boobs. If you're such a boob, this book is for you.
